column4: howdy, folks.  I have kind of a stupid question: is there some way to print out the current operating system version?  uname doesn't do what I want; I want scripts that recognize whether they're running in ubuntu or debian, since I share a home directory between the two.
you can also check for /etc/lsb-release and /etc/redhat-release
right, but I'm trying to connect through gnome.  Command-line options aren't an option
unless it's possible to specify the command gnome-vfs uses for smb:// URLs
it's probably not smbclient anyway - it uses 139 by default
not on my machine it doesn't.  When I run it from the command line, it times out twice trying to connect to 128.148.254.10:445 before it finally successfully connects to port 139
unless I specify port=139, in which case it works right away
you would think that this kind of thing can be configured in gnome...
Can't seem to find a way
Can't specify the port after the server (ie, smb://foo.bar.com:139/), as gnome doesn't understand it
